org.jtestdb.selenium.jscov

Class JscovTestUtil

  • Object
    • org.jtestdb.selenium.jscov.JscovTestUtil

  • public class JscovTestUtil
extends Object
    Class that is designed to interact with JSCover (a Javascript code-coverage tool) while executing test-case scripts within a Selenium v3 environment. JscovTestUtil class’ purpose is to provided methods that facilitate getting code-coverage of Javascript for a web-page, without manual intervention to instrument JS-files. It is assumed the user knows the JS-files the web-page and web-site will present, so as to allow management and control (include/exclude) code-coverage capture needs.

    Licensed under MIT.

    Supplemental documentation: please take the time to read the supplement, it provides some under-the-hood understanding of JscovTestUtil and interaction with JSCover and IDE integration.

    Skip to summaries: constructor

    Test scripting

    Test-case code/scripts are written normally, navigating the webpage-under-test (WUT) to do tests. JscovTestUtil provides methods that 'bracket' around the test-case scripts to control interaction with the JSCover program. This bracketing is most effective in the 'before-suite', 'before-class', 'after-class' and 'after-suite' methods used for test-script setup/configuration arrangements.

    JscovTestUtil does not support multi-threaded operation, implying test-scripts need to run in sequence, rather than parallel.

    Why is this the case?

    JSCover is used to perform the code-coverage and is external to the test-scripts: getting reports causes writing to files. These writes do not support concurrent usage, thus not conducive to parallel test-script report calls.

    However:

    Parallel testing is possible by the test-scripts interacting directly with the Javascript code (once the web-page is loaded)
        ((JavascriptExecutor) someWebDriver.executeScript(< java-script method >);
    As documented in the JSCover manual about running in a unit-test mode.

    Rather than driving the Javascript through actions/invocations via the web-page elements: which would typically be in sequence actions in a manner similar to actions through the UI.
        do 'buttonElement.click();' which calls buttonAction()

    How JscovTestUtil works

    See supplemental Supplemental documentation.

    The following diagram and its ordered steps is a brief on how JscovTestUtil interacts with hi-level "components" to do Javascript code-coverage, in a test Selenium (Java) and @Test framework environment.

    1. Test setup:
      • Start the proxy-server via ProcessBuilder from the JSCover executable directory.
    2. Testing:
      • Begin executing tests, perform GET-URL action.
        • Proxy-server: passes GET requests directly to web-server.
    3. Web-server:
      • Respond to GET requests and sends files back to requestor (for files: HTML, CSS, JS,...).
      1. Proxy-server: Javascript file(s) are intercepted by JSCover proxy-server and instrumented, if not excluded from instrumentation.
      2. Proxy-server: Instrumented files are forwarded to browser.
      3. Proxy-server: Excluded from instrumentation files are passed-through to the browser.
      4. Proxy-server: Records the original Javascript and retains them in the JSCover reports directory.
    4. Testing:
      • Performs normal test actions via the WebDriver API.
    5. Testing/capture report:
      • invoke a store-report at end of each test, or during testing, or whenever.
      1. Instrumented Javascript: Invoke the jscoverage_report(...) function in the instrumented Javascript. This will cause the script to forward captured results to the proxy-server directly.
      2. Proxy-server: Receives jscoverage JSON and other datum which will be formatted and converted into JSCover report format files.
      3. Proxy-server: Report-files are stored in the JSCover reports directory. JSCover will also merge the data if existing datum files present.
    6. Testing/stop:
      • On testing stop a request to terminate and stop the proxy-server is "called". This will cause a store-report first before stopping the JSCover proxy-server process on the system.

    JscovTestUtil requires Selenium V3 to be in place as a class-path library for testing purposes, alongside the JSCover program files/structure installed on the local machine. (See https://tntim96.github.io/JSCover for information about JSCover.)

    Dependencies

    Dependencies table
    class-path installed program or executable
    1) J2SE/JSEE V8 3) JSCover

    -- Needs the installation on a local machine of the JSCover program/software (see https://tntim96.github.io/JSCover).
    2) org.openqa.selenium classes

    -- no selenium code has been modified

    		 4) WebDriver executables

    -- These are the Selenium drivers that need to be put in place for normal Selenium operation.

    Top of summaries

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      JscovTestUtil(int portNo, String reportDirectory)
      Create a JscovTestUtil object where the JSCover-directory is contained within the "user-dir" of the current running environment (an IDE may be).

      The JSCover-directory for this mode is
            ' <user-dir>/jscoverInst '
      and as such the JSCover zip file needs to be extracted into the 'jscoverinst' directory directly.
      JscovTestUtil(int portNo, String reportDirectory, String externalJscoverDir)
      Create a JscovTestUtil object where the JSCover-directory is an external directory and separate from the test environment.

      This will require the user to have some experience in using and setting up JSCover on their system. The external directory will allow the user to manage multiple test environments using the same JSCover-structures.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      String getLastTimeStampReport()
      Get the last time-stamped report name from the reports directory, null if not found.
      String getProxyServerString()
      Get the proxy-server as a string ('http://localhost-proxy:nnnn').
      JscovTestUtil optionAddGeneric(String... listOfOptionStrings)
      Add JSCover options to the proxy-server process executable ("--port" and "--report-dir" are denied as they are set by the constructor). All other options are accepted but not checked (implying options that are not JSCover will cause the proxy-server not to launch, with unknown consequences).

      WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.
      JscovTestUtil optionClearAnyAdded()
      Clear any additional JSCover options that were added.
      JscovTestUtil optionNoInstrument(String... urlJsFiles)
      Add a JS-file to the "--no-instrument" option, implying all other files will be instrumented. The parameters are a URL as it pertains to the web-page being tested (see full Javadoc.)
      WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.
      JscovTestUtil optionNoInstrumentReg(String... regexOfJsFile)
      Add a '--no-instrument-reg=URL' option in its regex format for the proxy-server. The regex is a JVM regular expression which can be involved to achieve desired effect. See regex patterns examples for optionNoInstrumentReg and optionOnlyInstrumentReg.

      WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.
      JscovTestUtil optionOnlyInstrumentReg(String... regexOfJsFile)
      Add a '--only-instrument-reg=URL' option in its regex format for the proxy-server. The regex is a JVM regular expression which can be involved to achieve desired effect. See regex patterns examples for optionNoInstrumentReg and optionOnlyInstrumentReg.

      WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.
      WebDriver overrideWebDriveForJSCoverProxy(WebDriver aProxyConfiguresWebDriver)
      WARNING: This method will override the proxy-set Webdriver with the class object. It is intended for testing WebDriver classes (such as HtmlUnitDriver, which would require special class-path arrangements outside of normal Selenium V3 main stream browsers.
      void removeAllReports()
      Clean the reports directory of all sub-directories effectivily deletes all the held reports.

      WARNING: there is no recovery from this action :WARNING
      JscovTestUtil reportIntoReuseDir(int retainNTimestampReports, String reuseTimeStampDirectory)
      Reporting is to reuse the time-stamp directory that is provided. This allows merging of results/reports into a single time-stamped directory. Or a none time-stamp name may be used to override as a standalone sub-directory to report into.
      JscovTestUtil reportIntoSubDir(String furtherSubDir)
      Set report into a sub-directory of the "reports/<reportDirectory>" directory with furtherSubDir value (<reportDirectory> is set by the constructor call).
      JscovTestUtil reportIntoTimeStampDir(int retainNTimestampReports)
      Set report into the "reports/<reportDirectory>" directory and into a time-stamped sub-directory (jscovYYYYMMDD_hhmmdd_mmm) (<reportDirectory> is set by the constructor call).
      void restartProxyServer(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
      Restart the proxy-server which causes the proxy-server to stopProxyServer and then startProxyServer again.

      This method allows the user to change JS-file filters b=prior to continuing tests. Any changes to the "instrumentation" filters should be applied before calling this method.

      CAUTION: Has the potential to fail to provide full reports (some JS-files missing in report) if the system is slow due to under heavy load.
      JscovTestUtil setOffCodeCoverage()
      Set the JscovTestUtil object to a not-active mode so that actual code-coverage does not happen. HOWEVER, the test case script do not need to be changed in their use of start, store-report and stop method calls.
      JscovTestUtil setOffViewReport()
      Set the view-report state to OFF when the viewReportDo method is invoked within the test-scripts. The view-report will not popup.
      JscovTestUtil setOnCodeCoverage()
      Set the JscovTestUtil object to an active mode so that code-coverage capture will happen as the start, store-report and stop methods are invoked.
      JscovTestUtil setOnViewReport()
      Set the view-report state to ON when the viewReportDo method is invoked within the test-scripts. This will result in an independent process being launched and popup a browser to the "reports".
      void startProxyServer()
      Start the proxy-server, checking that resources are in place. Start may be called many times, only the first one will do the actual start.
      void stopProxyServer(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
      Stop the proxy-server running but first perform a 'store-report' action to create/append code-coverage to the reports directory.
      void storeJscoverReport(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
      Store the report into the JSCover-structure-directory as provided in the report-directory provided via the constructor methods. JSCover support the automatic merging of reports while reporting into the same directories, this allows multiple store-report calls allowed.
      void tearDownProxyServer(boolean force)
      Teardown the proxy-server without any reports. In the event of test-case failure with the proxy-server in started mode, the user will need to teardown the server.
      void viewReportDo(int viewingServerPortNo)
      View report in the default-browser when the testing has completed.
      static WebDriver webDriverForBrowser(JscovBrowserKind browserKind)
      Allocate a WebDriver for the JscovTestUtil kind of browser that is not a JscovTestUtil JSCover configured browser.
      WebDriver webDriverForJSCoverProxy(JscovBrowserKind jscoverBrowserKind)
      Allocate a WebDriver for JSCover proxy-server interaction that is controlled through a JscovTestUtil object and is of the JscovTestUtil kind of browser..
      static WebDriver webDriverForTypeSameAs(WebDriver otherDriver)
      Allocate a same-as WebDriver type based on another driver object provided.

    • Constructor Detail

      • JscovTestUtil

        public JscovTestUtil(int portNo,
                     String reportDirectory)
        Create a JscovTestUtil object where the JSCover-directory is contained within the "user-dir" of the current running environment (an IDE may be).

        The JSCover-directory for this mode is
              ' <user-dir>/jscoverInst '
        and as such the JSCover zip file needs to be extracted into the 'jscoverinst' directory directly.

        The 'JSCover-all.jar' used for running the proxy-server is located in the
              ' <user-dir>/jscoverInst/target/dist '
        directory, which JscovTestUtil will assume to be the case.

        Parameters:
        portNo - the port number of the JScover proxy-server
        reportDirectory - string that is a sub-directory to use for storing reports into (as per JSCover 'local-storage' option) [this directory will be created if missing in '<user-dir>/jscoverInst']

        Its is recommended that the user sets this reportDirectory to be "ignored" by GIT/HG/SVN/... source code management on their IDE project.

      • JscovTestUtil

        public JscovTestUtil(int portNo,
                     String reportDirectory,
                     String externalJscoverDir)
        Create a JscovTestUtil object where the JSCover-directory is an external directory and separate from the test environment.

        This will require the user to have some experience in using and setting up JSCover on their system. The external directory will allow the user to manage multiple test environments using the same JSCover-structures.
        Parameters:
        portNo - the port number of the JSCover proxy-server
        reportDirectory - string that is a sub-directory to use for storing reports into (as per JSCover 'local-storage' option) [this directory will be created if missing in the external directory location (locationOfJscoverDir)].
        externalJscoverDir - the location of the JSCover-directory where the JScover files are, as an absolute file path on the local system

      • getLastTimeStampReport

      • reportIntoReuseDir

        public JscovTestUtil reportIntoReuseDir(int retainNTimestampReports,
                                        String reuseTimeStampDirectory)
        Reporting is to reuse the time-stamp directory that is provided. This allows merging of results/reports into a single time-stamped directory. Or a none time-stamp name may be used to override as a standalone sub-directory to report into.

        Use the getLastTimeStampReport() to get the name of the last time-stamp report name.

        Parameters:
        retainNTimestampReports - the number of report directories with time-stamps to be retained in the reporting directory (0 means retain all)
        reuseTimeStampDirectory - the directory-name of an existing time-stamped directory. (No check is made for existence or if its a time-stamped name. Additional, if its a none time-stamped name it will override the existing report sub-directory setting).
        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if retainNTimestampReports is negative
        RuntimeException - if reuseTimeStampDirectory is null or an empty string

      • reportIntoSubDir

        public JscovTestUtil reportIntoSubDir(String furtherSubDir)
        Set report into a sub-directory of the "reports/<reportDirectory>" directory with furtherSubDir value (<reportDirectory> is set by the constructor call). This will cause the retain value for time-stamps to be reset to 0.

        The path for the reports to be placed is: 

         <JSCover-directory>/reports/<reportDirectory>/<furtherSubDir>/
        Parameters:
        furtherSubDir - name of the sub-directory to use
        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings

      • reportIntoTimeStampDir

        public JscovTestUtil reportIntoTimeStampDir(int retainNTimestampReports)
        Set report into the "reports/<reportDirectory>" directory and into a time-stamped sub-directory (jscovYYYYMMDD_hhmmdd_mmm) (<reportDirectory> is set by the constructor call).

        Only if the JscovTestUtil is running and started, otherwise this call is ignored. That is, reporting will remain into the same directory during active running.

        The path for the reports to be placed is: 

         <JSCover-directory>/reports/<reportDirectory>/<jscovYYYYMMDD_hhmmdd_mmm>/
        Parameters:
        retainNTimestampReports - the number of report directories with time-stamps to be retained in the reporting directory (0 means retain all) after code-coverage is stopped
        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if retainNTimestampReports is negative

      • setOffCodeCoverage

        public JscovTestUtil setOffCodeCoverage()
        Set the JscovTestUtil object to a not-active mode so that actual code-coverage does not happen. HOWEVER, the test case script do not need to be changed in their use of start, store-report and stop method calls.

        Test-case code may be written with the JscovTestUtil start, stop and store-report calls remaining in place. The 'setOnCodeCoverage/setOffCodeCoverage' methods are used to cause the on or off state of code-coverage-capture. Implying, in the test environment the user only needs to explicitly code the setOnCodeCoverage or setOffCodeCoverage methods.

        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the object is in a started proxy-server state already.

      • setOffViewReport

        public JscovTestUtil setOffViewReport()
        Set the view-report state to OFF when the viewReportDo method is invoked within the test-scripts. The view-report will not popup.
        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings

      • setOnCodeCoverage

        public JscovTestUtil setOnCodeCoverage()
        Set the JscovTestUtil object to an active mode so that code-coverage capture will happen as the start, store-report and stop methods are invoked.

        Test-case code may be written with the JscovTestUtil start, stop and store-report calls remaining in place. The 'setOnCodeCoverage/setOffCodeCoverage' methods are used to cause the on or off state of code-coverage-capture. Implying, in the test environment the user only needs to explicitly code the setOnCodeCoverage or setOffCodeCoverage methods.

        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the object is in a started proxy-server state already.

      • setOnViewReport

        public JscovTestUtil setOnViewReport()
        Set the view-report state to ON when the viewReportDo method is invoked within the test-scripts. This will result in an independent process being launched and popup a browser to the "reports".
        Returns:
        this object so as to cascade settings

      • startProxyServer

        public void startProxyServer()
        Start the proxy-server, checking that resources are in place. Start may be called many times, only the first one will do the actual start.

        The start will pause for 2 seconds to allow processes to actually start.

        Throws:
        RuntimeException - 1) location issues for the 'jscover' directory, or 2) 'target/dist/JSCover-all.jar' is not found as expected. 3) Failed to start the proxy-server.

      • stopProxyServer

        public void stopProxyServer(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
        Stop the proxy-server running but first perform a 'store-report' action to create/append code-coverage to the reports directory. Wait for a time-out period to get the report.

        Attempting to get a report from a 'stop' or 'report' action without prior use of 'webDriverForJSCoverProxy()'/'overrideWebDriveForJSCoverProxy' will not cause a report to generate and an ERR INFO message provided.

        Any storage management is performed (applies to time-stamped capability report capture).

        The stop will pause for 2 seconds to allow processes to actually stop.

        Processing to get reports is done in the browser/WebDriver and is external to this class. The user needs to determine a good time-out value for their environment.

        Parameters:
        timerForJscoverReport2Complete - time (seconds) allowed to process the code-coverage captured data into a report (small Javascript low time-out lots-of/large files more time needed [also, CPU speed or file access arrangement considerations].
        Throws:
        TimeoutException - if there is a time-out, consider lengthening the time-out for the web-page report generation
        JavascriptException - cannot find jscoverage_report in the web-page being processed (likely web-page not instrumented or page has closed before calling this method)

      • tearDownProxyServer

        public void tearDownProxyServer(boolean force)
        Teardown the proxy-server without any reports. In the event of test-case failure with the proxy-server in started mode, the user will need to teardown the server.

        tearDownProxyServer may be used at the beginning of a test-case with the force condition set. Invoking between 'start' and 'stop' states will impact processing in an undetermined manner.

        The ON or OFF states will remain as previously set.

        Parameters:
        force - true to send a stop message to the proxy-server

      • storeJscoverReport

        public void storeJscoverReport(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
        Store the report into the JSCover-structure-directory as provided in the report-directory provided via the constructor methods. JSCover support the automatic merging of reports while reporting into the same directories, this allows multiple store-report calls allowed.

        In the event that a test-case fails at least some report information may be collected.

        Attempting to get a report from a 'stop' or 'report' action without prior use of 'webDriverForJSCoverProxy()'/'overrideWebDriveForJSCoverProxy' will not cause a report to generate and an ERR INFO message provided.

        Concurrent test-cases doing store-reports is not supported. It may work, but?

        Parameters:
        timerForJscoverReport2Complete - time (seconds) allowed to process the code-coverage captured data into a report (small Javascript low time-out lots-of/large files more time needed [also, CPU speed or file access arrangement considerations].
        Throws:
        TimeoutException - if there is a time-out, consider lengthening the time-out for the web-page report generation
        JavascriptException - cannot find jscoverage_report in the web-page being processed (likely web-page not instrumented or page has closed before calling this method)

      • viewReportDo

        public void viewReportDo(int viewingServerPortNo)
        View report in the default-browser when the testing has completed. This is an involved process of:
        1. Determine if view-report is ON and the system is in a started-&-stopped state.
        2. Stop an existing JSCover SimpleWebServer using the same port number.

          This is done to deal with any changes of the JSCover installed directory between test runs.

        3. Start a NEW independent JSCover SimpleWebServer process with the port number provided.
        4. Launch the default browser and load the last report generate HTML file for viewing.

        Note: JSCover produces 'jscoverage.html' as the viewer-able report file, but JscovTestUtil modifies the file to 'jscovtestutil.html'. An additional added button to "stop the simple-server" is incorporated into 'jscovtestutil.html'.

        Only HTTP or HTTPS protocols support the stop button.

        Parameters:
        viewingServerPortNo - port number for the simpler-server

      • overrideWebDriveForJSCoverProxy

        public WebDriver overrideWebDriveForJSCoverProxy(WebDriver aProxyConfiguresWebDriver)
        WARNING: This method will override the proxy-set Webdriver with the class object. It is intended for testing WebDriver classes (such as HtmlUnitDriver, which would require special class-path arrangements outside of normal Selenium V3 main stream browsers. ??
        Parameters:
        aProxyConfiguresWebDriver - the driver with proxy settings set.
        Returns:
        the driver object

      • webDriverForJSCoverProxy

        public WebDriver webDriverForJSCoverProxy(JscovBrowserKind jscoverBrowserKind)
        Allocate a WebDriver for JSCover proxy-server interaction that is controlled through a JscovTestUtil object and is of the JscovTestUtil kind of browser..
        Parameters:
        jscoverBrowserKind - kind of browser to allocate driver for
        Returns:
        WebDriver object
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - browser kind is de-active

      • restartProxyServer

        public void restartProxyServer(int timerForJscoverReport2Complete)
        Restart the proxy-server which causes the proxy-server to stopProxyServer and then startProxyServer again.

        This method allows the user to change JS-file filters b=prior to continuing tests. Any changes to the "instrumentation" filters should be applied before calling this method.

        CAUTION: Has the potential to fail to provide full reports (some JS-files missing in report) if the system is slow due to under heavy load. The heavy load may cause the actual stop of JSCover proxy-server to be slow to shutdown (over 2 seconds), and/or the re-start of JSCover proxy-server to be ready to accept connections (over another 2 seconds).

        Why this method

        Why? change the JS-file filters such that proxy will instrument when a newer GET or a link to another page occurs.

         @Test(dependsOnMethods = {"selectConfigButt"})
 public void changeToDeviceConfig() {
   // will be changing the page but will change to newer
   // exclude JS-file from code-coverage
   jscovObject.optionClearAnyAdded()
              .optionNoInstrument("aes.js")
              .optionNoInstrument("subdir/wmospwd.js")
              .restartProxyServer(30);
   // prepare to goto different page
   //
   WebElement devAccPwdInputEle = driver.findElement(By.id("pwdcfg"));
   WebElement devAccCfgButtEle = driver.findElement(By.id("pwdbutt"));

   // change to a different page
   devAccPwdInputEle.sendKeys("somepassword");
   devAccCfgButtEle.click();
   pause(2000); // allow new page to load

   jscovObject.storeJscoverReport(30);
 }
        Parameters:
        timerForJscoverReport2Complete - time (seconds) allowed to process the code-coverage captured data into a report (small Javascript low time-out lots-of/large files more time needed [also, CPU speed or file access arrangement considerations].
        Throws:
        TimeoutException - if there is a time-out, consider lengthening the time-out for the web-page report generation
        JavascriptException - cannot find jscoverage_report in the web-page being processed (likely web-page not instrumented or page has closed before calling this method)

      • optionAddGeneric

        public JscovTestUtil optionAddGeneric(String... listOfOptionStrings)
        Add JSCover options to the proxy-server process executable ("--port" and "--report-dir" are denied as they are set by the constructor). All other options are accepted but not checked (implying options that are not JSCover will cause the proxy-server not to launch, with unknown consequences).

        WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.

        Duplicate options will be ignored.

        Removal of single options is not supported instead use clearAdditionalJSCoverOptions and re-add all other options.

        Parameters:
        listOfOptionStrings - list of the JSCover options as string
        Returns:
        this object

      • optionClearAnyAdded

        public JscovTestUtil optionClearAnyAdded()
        Clear any additional JSCover options that were added.
        Returns:
        this object

      • optionNoInstrument

        public JscovTestUtil optionNoInstrument(String... urlJsFiles)
        Add a JS-file to the "--no-instrument" option, implying all other files will be instrumented. The parameters are a URL as it pertains to the web-page being tested (see full Javadoc.)
        WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.

        Using this option allows a user to exclude certain JS-files from being instrumented by the JSCover proxy-server. Some of the reasons are:

        • A JS-file has been minified and as such many statements will appear on a single line of the JS-file. JSCover instruments a statement per line of the JS-file (so likely to fail and not make sense).
        • Wish to exclude a JS-file from the code-coverage collection.

        Of note, it is assumed that there are few JS-files involved in the web-page (less than 20).

        The URL-JS-File parameter is an exact match to the files to be loaded. In simple terms: Javascript files are HTTP GET requested due to the <script src... > tag:

         <script type="text/javascript" src="./subdir/file1.js"></script>
 <script type="text/javascript" src="./file2.js"></script>
 <script type="text/javascript" src="/file3.js"></script>

        UrlJsFile would contain the URL of the file (as it pertains to the above paths):

         /subdir/file1.js   or    subdir/file1.js
 /file2.js          or    file2.js
 /file3.js          or    file3.js
        Parameters:
        urlJsFiles - list of URLs for each JS-file (too many of these could use up the OSs command-line buffer size)
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - provided a null or empty string

      • optionNoInstrumentReg

        public JscovTestUtil optionNoInstrumentReg(String... regexOfJsFile)
        Add a '--no-instrument-reg=URL' option in its regex format for the proxy-server. The regex is a JVM regular expression which can be involved to achieve desired effect. See regex patterns examples for optionNoInstrumentReg and optionOnlyInstrumentReg.

        WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.

        Using this option allows a user to exclude certain JS-files from being instrumented by the JSCover proxy-server. Some of the reasons are:

        • A JS-file has been minified and as such many statements will appear on a single line of the JS-file. JSCover instruments a statement per line of the JS-file (so likely to fail and not make sense).
        • Wish to exclude a JS-file from the code-coverage collection.

        Of note, it is assumed that there are few JS-files involved in the web-page (less than 20).

        regex patterns examples

        Javascript files are HTTP GET requested due to the <script src... > tag:

         <script type="text/javascript" src="./subdir/file1.js"></script>
 <script type="text/javascript" src="./subdir/fileA1.js"></script>
 <script type="text/javascript" src="./file2.js"></script>
 <script type="text/javascript" src="/file3.js"></script>

        regexOfJsFile regex-pattern that match URL of the file (as it pertains to the above paths). Regex can be involved and deal with complex abilities to match patterns. For JscovTestUtil very simple patterns are recommended, for more involved patterns consult external Java regex expertise.

        Following are simple positive matches (note: '\' needs to be coded as '\\' in Java)

        regex to string
        regex-pattern ./subdir/file1.js ./subdir/fileA1.js ./file2.js /file3.js simple wildcard coded as

        ^.*dir.file.*$

        		 X X - - *dir*file*

        ^.*file.*$

        		 X X X X *file*

        ^.*file.*1.*$

        		 X X - - *file*1*

        ^.*file3.*$

        		 - - - X *file3*

        ^.*file2.*$

        		 - - X - *file2*

        ^.*2.*$

        		 - - X - *2*

        ^.*file3\.js$

        		 - - - X *file3.js ^.*file3\\.js$

        ^.*subdir.*$

        		 X X - - *subdir*

        ^.*file[32].*$

        		 - - X X

        ^.*file[321].*$

        		 X - X X

        ^.*file.*[321].*$

        		 X X X X

        ^.*file.*[13].*$

        		 X X - X

        ^.*file.*[3].*$|^.*file.*[1].*$

        		 X X - X regex or condition

        ^.*file.*[A].*$|^.*file.*[3].*$

        ^.*file.*[A].*$|^.*file[3].*$

        ^.*file.*[A].*$|^.*file3.*$

        		 - X - X regex or condition
        Parameters:
        regexOfJsFile - the regex-pattern to match with JSCover when doing instrumentation (too many of these could use up the OSs command-line buffer size)
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - provided a null or empty string
        PatternSyntaxException - If the expression's syntax is invalid ( do not ignore this)

      • optionOnlyInstrumentReg

        public JscovTestUtil optionOnlyInstrumentReg(String... regexOfJsFile)
        Add a '--only-instrument-reg=URL' option in its regex format for the proxy-server. The regex is a JVM regular expression which can be involved to achieve desired effect. See regex patterns examples for optionNoInstrumentReg and optionOnlyInstrumentReg.

        WARNING: Too many options will cause command-line buffer overrun and the startProxyServer may fail.

        Using this option allows a user to restrict code-coverage to certain JS-files to being instrumented by the JSCover proxy-server.

        Of note, it is assumed that there are few JS-files involved in the web-page (less than 20).

        Parameters:
        regexOfJsFile - the regex-pattern to match with JSCover when doing instrumentation (too many of these could use up the OSs command-line buffer size)
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - provided a null or empty string
        PatternSyntaxException - If the expression's syntax is invalid ( do not ignore this)
